questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Ichthyosis vulgaris is an Autosomal Dominant disorder.

  • It is a skin disorder marked by roughness, dryness, and scaling due to abnormal keratinisation.
  • Typically caused by loss-of-function mutations in the filaggrin (FLG) gene. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern with variable penetrance.
  • There are three main subtypes of ichthyosis based on genetic and clinical features:
    • Ichthyosis vulgaris (autosomal dominant)
    • X-linked ichthyosis (X-linked recessive)
    • Harlequin ichthyosis (autosomal recessive).

Explanation of other options:

X-linked recessive (Option A): This pattern is typical of X-linked ichthyosis, caused by steroid sulfatase deficiency, not ichthyosis vulgaris.

X-linked dominant (Option B) : Rare in ichthyoses; not the pattern seen in ichthyosis vulgaris.

Autosomal recessive (Option C) : Seen in more severe forms like harlequin ichthyosis , lamellar ichthyosis or congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma, not ichthyosis vulgaris.

questions.text: Acquired ichthyosis is associated with all expect?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Acquired ichthyosis is often associated with systemic diseases, particularly malignancies and chronic conditions.

Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1–L3 serovars), and it is not associated with acquired ichthyosis.

questions.text: A male child with cryptorchidism presents with large black scales on body as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The diagnosis is X-linked ichthyosis nigra, which is inherited in an X-linked recessive pattern and typically affects males, explaining the presence of the condition in this male child.

  • Ichthyosis nigra is caused by a mutation in the steroid sulfatase (STS) enzyme.
  • Clinically, it presents with hyperkeratosis, skin barrier dysfunction, and large, dark brown to black, geometrically shaped adherent scales with generalized distribution, including flexural areas.
  • It is commonly associated with cryptorchidism and corneal opacities

Explanation of other options:

Ichthyosis vulgaris (Option A) , Ichthyosis-lamellar (Option B), and Nodulous ichthyosiform erythroderma (Option D) do not typically present with the characteristic dark, adherent scales, male-only pattern, or the strong association with cryptorchidism seen in X-linked ichthyosis nigra.

Ichthyosis vulgaris

Lamellar ichthyosis

Explanation of answer:

The granular layer is absent or markedly reduced in ichthyosis vulgaris.

  • In ichthyosis vulgaris, there is a loss-of-function mutation in the filaggrin (FLG) gene, which leads to defective keratinization. As a result, the stratum granulosum (granular layer) is either absent or significantly thinned on histology.
  • Filaggrin is normally stored in keratohyalin granules, and its deficiency impairs the formation of the granular layer and skin barrier.
  • This condition is characterized histologically by compact hyperkeratosis and a thinned or absent stratum granulosum, along with increased stratum corneum thickness.

Explanation of other options:

X-linked ichthyosis (Option B) and Lamellar ichthyosis (Option D) do not show absence of the granular layer. In Epidermolytic hyperkeratosis (Option C), the granular layer is actually thickened due to a process called granular degeneration.

X Linked Ichthyosis

Lamellar Ichthyosis

choices.text: The presence of a collodion membrane is diagnostic of lamellar ichthyosis.
Most colloidion babies do not survive beyond the neonatal period.
Collodion baby is a clinical phenotype that may evolve into various forms of ichthyosis.
The collodion membrane always peels off within 24 hours of birth.

questions.text: A dermatology referral was called for a newborn baby. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

A collodion baby represents a transient presentation that may evolve into various forms of ichthyosis.

  • A neonate born encased in a tight, shiny, transparent membrane (like cellophane or wax), known as a collodion membrane.
  • This is not a specific disease but a transient phenotype seen in several underlying disorders. Lamellar ichthyosis, congenital ichthyosiform erythroderma, or even self-healing collodion baby. (Option A ruled out)
  • Typically autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • The membrane typically sheds over 2 to 4 weeks, often revealing ichthyosis, most commonly non bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma or lamellar ichthyosis. (Option D ruled out)
  • Complications: Dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, temperature instability, infection due to impaired skin barrier.
  • With supportive care, many colloidion babies survive. Especially those with self-healing types may recover completely. Mortality depends on complications like dehydration, infection, or temperature instability (Option B ruled out)
  • Management:
    • Supportive care in a humidified incubator
    • Emollients, careful monitoring, prevent infections
  • Lamellar Ichthyosis:
    • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive.
    • Defect: Defect in transglutaminase enzyme.
    • Onset – Born as collodion baby with collodion membrane over time, this membrane ruptures and presents as lamellar ichthyosis
    • Clinical features – Child is wrapped in shiny, parchment membrane. (Like cellophane sheet)
    • Membrane ruptures within 2-4 weeks to reveal lamellar ichthyosis.

questions.text: What is the genetic defect in the disease shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

Harlequin ichthyosis (HI), also known as 'ichthyosis fetalis', is an extremely rare autosomal recessive congenital ichthyosis (ARCI), affecting the ABCA12 gene.

  • Affected neonates are usually born prematurely.
  • Characteristic features:
    • Thick, yellow, armor-like scales covering the body
    • Deep red fissures (longitudinal and transverse)
    • Mitten-like hands and feet due to tight, hard skin
    • Severe ectropion (outward turning eyelids) exposing conjunctiva
    • Flattened nose and everted lips

Explanation of other options:

  • Steroid sulfatase deficiency (Option A) is seen in X-linked ichthyosis
  • SPINK5 gene mutation (Option C) is associated with Netherton syndrome
  • The transglutaminase 1 gene mutation (Option D)  is in lamellar ichthyosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with high-grade fever for 5 days followed by the development of painful erythematous plaques on her face and upper limbs. On examination, the lesions are tender, raised, and edematous. A skin biopsy shows dense neutrophilic infiltrate in the upper dermis without evidence of vasculitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The most probable diagnosis is Sweet syndrome, a neutrophilic dermatosis characterized by the sudden onset of fever and painful erythematous plaques or nodules, as seen in this patient. Skin biopsy typically shows dense neutrophilic infiltration, confirming the diagnosis.

Key features of Sweet syndrome:

  • Acute onset of painful, well-defined red plaques or nodules
  • Often associated with fever and arthralgia
  • Commonly affects the face, neck, and limbs
  • Histopathology: neutrophilic infiltrate in the dermis
  • Maybe:
    • Idiopathic (most common)
    • Associated with:
      • Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease)
      • Rheumatoid arthritis
      • Myeloproliferative disorders (especially acute myeloid leukemia or myelodysplastic syndromes)
  • Treatment options:
    • Steroids (first-line), dapsone, colchicine

Sweet syndrome

Pyoderma gangrenosum

Explanation of other options:

ENL (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum) (Option A)  and Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option C) present differently and do not primarily show neutrophilic dermal infiltrates with this acute presentation.

ENL (Option A): Seen in lepromatous leprosy, presents with nodules over extensor surfaces, not typically on the face; biopsy shows neutrophils with vasculitis and fragmented bacilli.

Pyoderma gangrenosum (Option C): Typically presents as painful ulcers with undermined borders; histology may show neutrophils, but clinical appearance is ulcerative rather than plaque-like.

Lupus erythematosus (Option D): Lesions are photosensitive and non-tender; histology reveals interface dermatitis and basement membrane thickening, not dense dermal neutrophils.

questions.text: A person with recurrent painful oral and genital ulcers along with painful nodules on extensor aspect of legs as shown. What is diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The presence of recurrent painful oral and genital ulcers along with painful nodules on the legs (erythema nodosum-like lesions) is characteristic of Behçet's syndrome. Behçet's is a rare, immune-mediated systemic vasculitis.

Key diagnostic features include:

  • Triple-symptom complex:
    • Recurrent oral aphthous ulcers
    • Genital ulcers
    • Ocular involvement (e.g., uveitis)
  • Association with HLA: B5
  • Additional findings:
    • Erythema nodosum or cutaneous pustular vasculitis
    • Positive pathergy test
  • Diagnosis (ITR-ICBD criteria):
    • 2 points each: Genital ulcers, ocular lesions
    • 1 point each: Oral ulcers, skin lesions, vascular involvement, pathergy
    • ≥3 points confirms diagnosis
  • The pathergy test shows an exaggerated inflammatory response to minor skin trauma.
    • A slight prick with a needle on the flexor surface of the arm is performed.
    • About 48 hours later, a papule or pustule appears at the site of the prick, this would not normally happen.
    • Koebner phenomenon, where trauma leads to morphologically similar lesions of the underlying disease.
    • In the pathergy test, you only get a papule or pustule.
    • Besides Behcet's disease, the pathergy test can sometimes be positive in patients with pyoderma gangrenosum.
    • Eye involvement is significant, causing anterior and posterior uveitis.
    • Sometimes, patients can develop panuveitis, retinal vasculitis.

Explanation of other options:

Pemphigus (Option B) , Herpes genitalis ( Option C) , and Fixed drug eruption (Option D) are not present with the full triad of mucocutaneous ulcers and systemic signs seen in Behçet’s syndrome.

Pemphigus vulgaris

Herpes genitalis

Fixed drug eruption

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with painful swelling of the left knee and right ankle. He also complains of pain and redness in the right eye. On examination, there are hyperkeratotic skin lesions over the palms and soles, and a history of burning micturition with prior urethral discharge is elicited. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The most likely diagnosis is Reactive arthritis, given the combination of asymmetric joint pain (knee and ankle), conjunctivitis, urethral symptoms (burning micturition, discharge), and skin lesions- yellowish hyperkeratotic plaques/papules on the palms and soles. This fits the classic triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, known as Reiter’s syndrome, a form of reactive arthritis.

Features of reactive arthritis:

  • Triad of
    • Asymmetric oligoarthritis, commonly affecting lower limbs
    • Non-gonococcal urethritis
    • Conjunctivitis or uveitis
  • Skin findings:
    • Keratoderma blennorrhagicum (yellowish hyperkeratotic plaques on palms/soles)
    • Circinate balanitis in males, an asymptomatic, round-shaped inflammatory lesion on the glans penis.
    • Erythroderma nodosum
  • Occurs 1–4 weeks after an infection, commonly:
    • Genitourinary: Chlamydia trachomatis
    • Gastrointestinal: Campylobacter jejuni (most common), Salmonella enteritidis, Shigella flexneri, Yersinia enterocolitica
  • Investigations
    • ↑ ESR, CRP
    • Negative synovial fluid culture
    • Maybe HLA-B27 positive
    • Infection workup: urine PCR for Chlamydia, stool culture if GI origin suspected
  • Management
    • NSAIDs: First-line for arthritis
    • Antibiotics: For triggering infection (esp. Chlamydia)
    • DMARDs (e.g., sulfasalazine, methotrexate): In chronic/refractory cases

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A) is incorrect due to its symmetric joint involvement. The clinical features are symmetrical polyarthritis (especially small joints of hands and feet), morning stiffness, rheumatoid nodules, positive RF and anti-CCP.

Psoriasis (Option C) may cause arthritis and skin lesions, but lacks urethritis/conjunctivitis. Clinical features include chronic scaly plaques (especially on extensor surfaces), nail pitting, and, in psoriatic arthritis, dactylitis, enthesitis, and asymmetric oligoarthritis.

Secondary syphilis (Option D) can involve palms/soles, but doesn’t present with arthritis or urethritis in this pattern. Clinical features are generalized maculopapular rash including palms and soles, mucous patches, condylomata lata, lymphadenopathy and systemic symptoms.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of painful oral ulcer as shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The lesion in the given image is consistent with an aphthous ulcer. These are small, recurrent, painful, round or ovoid ulcers with a central yellow or gray base and a well-defined erythematous halo-like margin.

Common sites:

  • Lining mucosa: buccal and labial mucosa, underside of the tongue
  • Not typically found on attached gingiva or hard palate

Explanation of other options:

Option (B) Herpes, Option (C) Herpangina, and Option (D) Varicella are incorrect, as they usually present with multiple vesicles or ulcers, often involving different areas (e.g., gingiva, soft palate, pharynx) and are usually associated with systemic symptoms like fever.

Herpes

  • It is a viral skin lesion caused by Herpes simplex virus (HHV 1 - 8)

Herpangina

  • Viral skin infection caused by coxsackie A1-10, B, E71
  • Lesions are painful vesicles
  • The most common site is the posterior pharynx

Varicella

  • Caused by the varicella zoster virus
  • Incubation period of 10 - 14 days
  • Clinical features are fever and vesicles all over the body
  • Lesions follow a centripetal distribution

questions.text:
A 5-day-old neonate is brought with recurrent seizures since birth. On examination, a port-wine stain is noted over the left side of the face, involving the forehead and upper eyelid (V1 distribution). CT brain shows tram track calcifications. Neonate also shows a facial vascular lesion as given in the image
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The most likely diagnosis is Sturge-Weber syndrome (SWS) and the image shows a classic port-wine stain.

Key features of Sturge-Weber syndrome:

  • Port-wine stain (nevus flammeus): Present at birth, usually unilateral, and located in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (ophthalmic/maxillary branches).
  • Seizures: Often the first neurological sign, typically begins in infancy and affects the side opposite the brain lesion.
  • Neuroimaging: Tram-track calcifications on CT indicate leptomeningeal angiomas, a hallmark of SWS.
  • Ocular involvement: Increased risk of glaucoma, especially if both upper and lower eyelids are involved.

Explanation of other options:

Tuberous sclerosis (Option A): Associated with hypopigmented ash-leaf spots, cortical tubers, seizures, and subependymal nodules; not port-wine stains or leptomeningeal angiomas.

Klippel-Trénaunay syndrome (Option B): Involves capillary malformation, limb hypertrophy, and venous anomalies; CNS involvement and seizures are not typical.

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (Option D): Features include café-au-lait spots, axillary freckling, Lisch nodules, and neurofibromas, not port-wine stains or early neonatal seizures.

questions.text: A newborn had reddish swelling over the upper eyelid, and the swelling regressed spontaneously at about one year of age. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The newborn’s reddish swelling over the upper eyelid that regressed spontaneously by one year is characteristic of a nevus simplex (salmon patch).

Features of  nevus simplex (salmon patch):

  • A common vascular birthmark in 30–40% of newborns
  • Dilated venous capillaries in the skin (a vascular malformation) / Ectasia of the blood vessels.
  • Appears as pale pink, ill-defined vascular macules
  • Common sites: eyelids, glabella, upper lip, and nuchal area
  • When present on the forehead - "angel's kiss" and when present on the nape of the neck - "stork bite".
  • Often symmetric, involving both eyelids or both sides of the midline
  • Becomes more visible with crying or temperature changes
  • Lesions on the face usually fade completely within the first year

Explanation of other options:

Nevus flammeus (Option A) Also known as port-wine stain; it is a non-regressing, flat capillary malformation that grows proportionally with the child.

Capillary hemangioma (Option B) grows in early infancy and may not regress by one year

Lymphangioma (Option D) Presents as soft, compressible, transilluminant lesions, often in the neck or axilla, and does not regress spontaneously; may enlarge with infection or trauma.

questions.text: The following lesion appears on the leg of a patient suffering from recurrent bouts of bloody diarrhoea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The lesion shows a painful ulcer with violaceous margins and undermined edges in a patient with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) presenting as recurrent bloody diarrhoea, classic of pyoderma gangrenosum.

Pyoderma gangrenosum

  • Commonly associated with autoimmune conditions like IBD, rheumatoid arthritis, and some malignancies.
  • Ulcers progress rapidly and are painful with irregular, violaceous, undermined borders.

Diagnostic Criteria:

Major Criteria (both required):

  • Rapid progression of painful necrolytic ulcer with irregular violaceous and undermined borders
  • Exclusion of other causes of cutaneous ulcers

Minor Criteria (at least two required):

  • History of pathergy or cribriform scarring
  • Associated systemic diseases (e.g., IBD)
  • Histopathology showing sterile dermal neutrophilic infiltrate ± mixed inflammation
  • Rapid improvement with systemic steroids

Explanation of other options:

Erythema nodosum (Option A): Tender red nodules (not ulcers) on legs

Erythema marginatum (Option B): Associated with rheumatic fever; not linked to IBD or ulcers.

Sweet syndrome (Option D): Presents with tender, erythematous, edematous plaques, not ulcers.

Explanation of answer:

Kasabach-Merritt syndrome (KMS) is characterised by the triad of:

  • Giant vascular tumour (hemangioma)
  • Thrombocytopenia due to platelet trapping and destruction within the tumour
  • Consumption coagulopathy (consumptive coagulopathy)

KMS is a rare but serious complication seen in rapidly growing vascular tumours in infants.

Platelet count drops because platelets get trapped and destroyed inside the expanding hemangioma.

The vascular tumour involved is typically an infantile hemangioma, the most common vascular tumour in infants.

Explanation of other options:

Mental retardation (Option A): Not a feature of Kasabach-Merritt syndrome.

Cataract (Option C): Seen in congenital infections or metabolic syndromes, not in this vascular-coagulopathy syndrome.

Nephropathy (Option D): Not associated with this condition.

choices.text: Most common site is neck and axilla

questions.text: Which of these is not true about the lesion in the image -
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The image depicts skin tags (acrochordons). Treatment of Skin tags is not mandatory.

Skin Tags

  • Common benign lesions caused by Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) (Option A ruled out).
  • Most frequently found on the neck, axilla, and other major flexures (Option B ruled out)
  • Associated with metabolic syndrome, obesity, diabetes, and acanthosis nigricans, possibly related to increased IGF-1 levels (Option D ruled out).
  • Treatment is not mandatory and is usually performed only for cosmetic reasons
  • Common treatment methods include cautery and cryotherapy

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought by parents with abdominal pain, joint aches, and a rash on his legs and feet. He does not have a history of frequent nosebleeds, easy bruising, or other episodes of abnormal bleeding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation of answer:

The presentation of abdominal pain, joint aches, and a rash on the legs and feet without bleeding history strongly supports Henoch-Schönlein purpura (IgA vasculitis) as the most likely diagnosis.

  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an IgA-mediated small vessel vasculitis affecting the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.
  • Clinical features – It’s a multisystemic disease. Commonly seen in children, history of URI
  • Characteristic features include palpable purpura (often on lower limbs), abdominal pain, arthralgias, and sometimes renal involvement (Glomerulonephritis leads to cola-colored urine or microscopic hematuria). Platelet count is normal.
  • Diagnosis is by:
    • Skin Biopsy
      • HPE: Vasculitis, Fibrinoid necrosis of BV wall
      • DIF: IgA, C3(vessel wall)
    • Kidney Biopsy
      • HPE: Mesangio-proliferative GN
      • DIF: IgA, C3
      • Kidney biopsy may show mesangio proliferative glomerulonephritis.
  • Treatment 
    • NSAIDS 
    • Systemic Steroids 
    • IVIG 
  • Complications 
    • RPGN, CKD

Explanation of other options:

Acute urticaria (Option A) usually presents with transient wheals without systemic symptoms like abdominal pain or arthralgia.

DIC (Option B) involves abnormal bleeding and systemic coagulopathy, which is absent here.

Erythema nodosum (Option C) presents as tender nodules rather than palpable purpura and is less commonly associated with abdominal pain or joint symptoms.
